{{Infobox software
| name = Oracle Grid Engine | logo = [[Image:GridEngine.png|middle|GridEngine Logo]] | developer = [[Oracle Corporation]] (formerly [[Sun Microsystems]]) in association with the community | latest release version = 6.2u7 | latest release date = {{release date|2010|12|24}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://markmail.org/thread/zlpfzzlfgbp7sd2x|first=Andy|last=Schwierskott|title=Go On and Good bye and Announcing Oracle Grid Engine 6.2 Update 7|date=2010-12-24}}</ref> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | genre = [[Grid computing]] | license = [[Sun Industry Standards Source License|SISSL]] | website = [http://www.oracle.com/us/products/tools/oracle-grid-engine-075549.html oracle.com] }}
'''Oracle Grid Engine''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun.com/software/sge/|title=Oracle Grid Engine|date=2010-05-303|publisher=Oracle Corporation}}</ref> previously known as ''Sun Grid Engine'' ('''SGE'''), '''CODINE''' (Computing in Distributed Networked Environments) or '''GRD''' (Global Resource Director),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sun.com/templedf/entry/a_little_history_lesson|title=A Little History Lesson|date=2006-06-23|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> is an [[open source]] [[batch-queuing system]], developed and supported by [[Sun Microsystems]]. Sun once also sold a commercial product based on SGE, known as '''N1 Grid Engine''' ('''N1GE''').
Grid Engine is open source and free to use from the project website under the [[Sun Industry Standards Source License]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gridengine.sunsource.net/license.html|title=The Grid Engine Source License|date=2010-06-04|publisher=Sun MicroSystems}}</ref> There is a commercial version available from the Oracle site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oracle.com/us/products/tools/oracle-grid-engine-075549.html|title=Oracle Grid Engine|date=2010-07-26|publisher=Oracle Corporation}}</ref> It appears that all further versions, starting from 6.2u6, will be commercial (with a 90-day free trial).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gridengine.sunsource.net/ds/viewMessage.do?dsForumId=38&dsMessageId=264919&orderBy=createDate&orderType=desc|title=A discussion at GridEngine forums|date=2010-06-29}}</ref>
SGE is typically used on a computer farm or [[high-performance computing]] (HPC) [[Cluster (computing)|cluster]] and is responsible for accepting, scheduling, dispatching, and managing the remote and distributed execution of large numbers of standalone, parallel or interactive user jobs. It also manages and schedules the allocation of distributed resources such as processors, memory, disk space, and [[software license]]s.
SGE is the foundation of the [[Sun Grid]] [[utility computing]] system, made available over the [[Internet]] in the [[United States]] in 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun.com/smi/Press/sunflash/2006-03/sunflash.20060322.1.xml|title=World's First Utility Grid Comes Alive on the Internet|date=2006-03-22|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> later becoming available in many other countries.
==Features== [[Image:Xml-qstat.jpg|thumb|290px|A screenshot of the xml-qstat web interface.]]
===Features new in version 6.2=== * Advance reservation * Array job interdependencies * Rule-based ''Resource Quota'' control<ref>[http://gridscheduler.sourceforge.net/howto/ResourceQuotaSpecification.html Specification: Resource Quota]</ref> * Enhanced remote execution (without using external rshd/rlogind/sshd processes) * Multi-clustering<ref>{{cite web| url = http://web.archive.org/web/20090105141229/http://hedeby.sunsource.net/ | title = Hedeby Project home| accessdate = 2008-01-25| publisher = Sun Microsystems}}</ref> * Daemons managed by the [[Service Management Facility]] on Solaris * [[Pseudo TTY]] (pty) support for interactive jobs * Job Submission Verifier (client-side and server-side job verification) * [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] Installer and SGE Inspect * Topology-aware scheduling and thread binding * [[Hadoop]] integration, [[Amazon EC2]] integration for cloud computing
Other features of SGE include:
* Multiple advanced [[scheduling algorithm]]s allow powerful policy-based resource allocation * Cluster queues * Job and scheduler fault tolerance - Grid Engine continues to operate as long as there is one or more hosts available * [[Application checkpointing|Job checkpointing]] * Job arrays and job tasks * [[DRMAA]] (Job API) * Resource reservation * XML status reporting (''qstat'' and ''qhost''), and the ''xml-qstat''<ref>{{cite web | url = http://olesenm.github.com/xml-qstat/ | title = xml-qstat | accessdate = 2009-10-12 | publisher = olesenm.github.com }}</ref> web interface * Parallel jobs ([[Message Passing Interface|MPI]], [[Parallel Virtual Machine|PVM]], [[OpenMP]]), and scalable parallel job startup with qrsh<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gridengine.sunsource.net/servlets/ReadMsg?listName=users&msgNo=9446 | title = Long delay when submitting large jobs (mailing list message) | accessdate = 2007-12-25 | publisher = Sun Microsystems }}</ref> * Usage accounting * Accounting and Reporting COnsole (ARCO) * parallel make: distmake, dmake ([[Sun Studio Compiler Suite|Sun Studio]]), and SGE's own qmake * [[FLEXlm]] integration<ref>{{cite web | url = http://olesenm.github.com/flex-grid/ | title = flex-grid | accessdate = 2009-10-12 | publisher = olesenm.github.com }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.gridengine.info/wiki/index.php/Olesen-FLEXlm-Integration | title = Olesen-FLEXlm-Integration | accessdate = 2007-12-25 | publisher = wiki.gridengine.info }}</ref> and multi-cluster software license management with ''LicenseJuggler''<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.gridengine.info/wiki/index.php/LicenseJuggler | title = LicenseJuggler | accessdate = 2007-12-26 | publisher = wiki.gridengine.info }}</ref>
==Platforms== SGE runs on multiple platforms, including: * [[AIX operating system|AIX]] * [[BSD]] - [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]], [[OpenBSD]] * [[HP-UX]] * [[IRIX]] * [[Linux]] * [[Mac OS X]] * [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] * [[SUPER-UX]] * [[Tru64]] * [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] via SFU ([[Interix]]) or SUA ([[Microsoft Windows Services for UNIX]]) (as execution hosts only) * [[Z/OS]] (in progress{{When|date=October 2011}})
==Cluster architecture== A typical Grid Engine cluster consists of a master host and one or more execution hosts. Multiple ''shadow masters'' can also be configured as [[hot spare]]s, which take over the role of the master when the original master host crashes.<ref>{{Cite web |title= How to Install the Shadow Master Host |url= http://wikis.sun.com/display/gridengine62u3/How+to+Install+the+Shadow+Master+Host |work= Sun Grid Engine 6.2u3 blog |date= August 27, 2009 |accessdate= October 6, 2011 }}</ref>
==Support and training== Sun provided support contracts for the commercial version of Grid Engine on most [[UNIX]] platforms and [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://store.sun.com/CMTemplate/CEServlet?process=SunStore&cmdViewProduct_CP&catid=115672 | title = Sun Store Grid Engine Entitlement Purchase | accessdate = 2008-03-03 | publisher = Sun Microsystems |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071030012101/http://store.sun.com/CMTemplate/CEServlet?process=SunStore&cmdViewProduct_CP&catid=115672 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-10-30}}</ref> Professional services, consulting, training, and support were provided by Sun Partners.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sun.com/software/gridware/partners/index.xml | title = Sun Grid Engine 6 Partners | accessdate = 2007-12-14 | publisher = Sun Microsystems }}</ref> Sun partners with [[Georgetown University]] to deliver Grid Engine administration classes.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blogs.sun.com/templedf/entry/advanced_sun_grid_engine_configuration | title = Advanced Sun Grid Engine Configuration and Administration Class | accessdate = 2007-12-14 | publisher = Sun Microsystems }}</ref> ''The Bioteam'' runs short SGE training workshops that are 1 or 2 days long.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.bioteam.net/category/training/ | title = Training | accessdate = 2008-03-24 | publisher = The Bioteam Inc.}}</ref>
Users obtained community support on the Grid Engine mailing lists.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gridengine.sunsource.net/maillist.html |deadurl= yes |title = Grid Engine Mail Lists |publisher = Sun Microsystems |archivedate= December 25, 2008 |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20081225034600/http://gridengine.sunsource.net/maillist.html |accessdate= October 6, 2011 }}</ref> Grid Engine Workshops were held in 2002, 2003, 2007, 2009, and 2012 in [[Regensburg, Germany]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gridengine.sunsource.net/workshop.html |deadurl= yes |title = Grid Engine Workshops |publisher = Sun Microsystems |archivedate= March 8, 2009 |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090308083532/http://gridengine.sunsource.net/workshop.html |accessdate= October 6, 2011 }}</ref>
==Users== Notable deployments of SGE include: * [[Sun Grid]] * the TSUBAME supercomputer at the [[Tokyo Institute of Technology]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sun.com/blueprints/0607/820-1695.html | title = Sun N1 Grid Engine Software and the Tokyo Institute of Technology Super Computer Grid | accessdate = 2007-11-16 | publisher = Sun Microsystems }}</ref> which was number 7 on June 2006 [[TOP500]] list. * Ranger at the [[Texas Advanced Computing Center]] (TACC). Ranger has 62,976 processor cores in 3,936 nodes and a peak performance of 504TFlops.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.tacc.utexas.edu/resources/hpcsystems/#ranger | title = TACC > HPC Systems | accessdate = 2007-12-13 | publisher = The University of Texas at Austin }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://blogs.sun.com/marchamilton/entry/more_ranger_facts_and_figures | title = More Ranger Facts and Figures | accessdate = 2008-02-12 | publisher = Sun Microsystems }}</ref> Ranger was the 4th most powerful TOP500 supercomputer in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://top500.org/list/2008/06/100|title=TOP500 List - June 2008|date=2006-06-18|publisher=TOP500.Org}}</ref> * [[San Diego Supercomputer Center]] (SDSC) * [[Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory]] (NOAA GFDL)
==History==<!-- This section is linked from [[Sun Microsystems]] --> In 2000, Sun acquired Gridware, Inc. a privately owned commercial vendor of advanced computing resource management software with offices in San Jose, Calif., and Regensburg, Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun.com/smi/Press/sunflash/2000-07/sunflash.20000724.3.xml|title=Gridware's resource management software increases efficiency and productivity in compute-intensive technical computing environments|date=2000-07-24|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> Later that year, Sun offered a free version of Gridware for Solaris and Linux, and renamed the product Sun Grid Engine.
In 2001, Sun made the [[source code]] available,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun.com/smi/Press/sunflash/2001-07/sunflash.20010723.1.xml|title=Sun Microsystems makes SUN GRID ENGINE software available to open source community|date=2001-07-23|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> and adopted the open source development model. Ports for Mac OS X and *BSD were contributed by the non-Sun open source developers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsdcan.org/2010/schedule/events/169.en.html|title=Porting HPC Tools to FreeBSD|date=2010-05-14}}</ref>
In 2010, after the purchase of Sun by Oracle, the Grid Engine 6.2 update 6 source code was not included with the binaries, and changes were not put back to the project's source repository. In response to this, the Grid Engine community started the [[Open Grid Scheduler]] project to continue to develop and maintain a free implementation of Grid Engine.<ref>[http://sourceforge.net/projects/gridscheduler/ Open Grid Scheduler]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linux-mag.com/id/7850|title=The State of Oracle/Sun Grid Engine|first=Douglas|last=Eadline, Ph.D.|date=September 1, 2010|accessdate=2011-01-18|publisher=Linux Magazine}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://markmail.org/message/hcxond5s4cywe5dv|title=Changes for a Bright Future at Oracle|first=Daniel|last=Templeton|date=2010-12-23|accessdate=2011-01-19}}</ref>
On January 18, 2011, it was announced that [[Univa]] had recruited several principal engineers from the former Sun Grid Engine team and that Univa would be developing their own [[Fork (software development)|forked]] version of Grid Engine. The newly announced [[Univa Grid Engine]] will include commercial support and would compete with the official version of Oracle Grid Engine.<ref>{{cite pressrelease|url=http://www.univa.com/about/news/press_2011/01172011.php|title=Univa Acquires Grid Engine Expertise|date=2011-01-18|publisher=Univa|accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hpcwire.com/features/Univa-Rescues-Grid-Engine-From-Oracle-114140804.html|title=Univa Rescues Grid Engine From Oracle|publisher=HPCwire|first=Michael|last=Feldman|date=2011-01-18|accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/01/18/univa_forks_oracle_grid_engine/|title=Univa forks Oracle's Sun Grid Engine|first=Timothy Prickett|last=Morgan|publisher=The Register|date=2011-01-18|accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref>
==Other Grid Engine based products== * [[Sun Constellation System]] * [[Sun Visualization System]] * Sun Compute Cluster<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sun.com/servers/hpc/computecluster/index.jsp|title=Sun Compute Cluster Solution|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> * ClusterVisionOS Distribution * [[Rocks Cluster Distribution]] * [[Univa]]'s [[UniCluster Express]] * [[Univa Grid Engine]] * BioTeam's iNquiry * [[Nimbus (cloud computing)|Nimbus]] - uses Grid Engine as a virtual machine scheduler in a cloud computing environment
==Add-on software== A number of SGE add-ons are available: * [[Solaris Cluster]] integration<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/819-3064/cacjgdbc?a=view|title=Installing and Configuring Sun Cluster HA for Sun Grid Engine|date=2008-02-15|publisher=Sun Microsystems}}</ref> * ''Service Domain Management'' module in order to meet [[service level agreement|service level objectives]] * Transfer-queue Over Globus (TOG). [[Globus Alliance|Globus]] added support for Grid Engine in [[Globus Toolkit]] 5.0.0<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globus.org/toolkit/docs/5.0/5.0.0/execution/gram5/rn/ |title=GT 5.0.0 Release Notes}}</ref> * JOb Scheduling Hierarchically (JOSH)
